Hi Peggy,  
The Seattle Department of Transportation implemented a similar pilot program in 2008: 
http://www.cityofseattle.net/transportation/pedpolicy_pedcrossingflags.htm 
Apparently the city had trouble procuring funding for maintenance of the program, but it may still be active. I would recommend contacting them to see if they can help with your specific questions. 
Seattle Department of Transportation 
(206) 684-7583 
WalkAndBike@Seattle.gov 
Hope this helps! Let me know if you need anything else. 
Derek Johnson

text:
The City of Wilsonville is interested in the viability of a pedestrian crossing flag program at street crossings that do not quality for additional traffic slowing devices.   (Buckets of bright flags available to pedestrians at each side of a crossing)     
Before creating a pilot for this, we are interested in:    1)  how are crossing sites selected for the flag program?      2)  what department manages the flag program?    3)  what liability does the city incur when promoting and/or supplying such a program?    4)   are the flags always at crossings that include a marked crosswalk?
Thank you,
Peggy Watters
Community Services Director
title: Pedestrian crossing flag liability
